results.title: The Ceiling of the Sistine Chapel
results.brief_description: A study of the Michelangelo paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican. At the beginning of the sixteenth century, Bramante drew the plans for the new Basilica of St. Peter. Raphael peopled the halls in the Vatican with figures and stories of ideal beauty and Michelangelo displayed on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel that history of mankind which bears witness to the superhuman task of a superhuman spirit.

results.title: The Cavity caper
results.creator_credit: Newfilms and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A dramatisation for children on the subject of dental care, in which Big Al and Louis try to outwit Kev Casual, but the Tooth Fairy comes to the rescue. The Army is also brought into the fight against plaque No other credits available. Cast includes Colin Friels. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: The Cave community

results.brief_description: Explains why the relatively unchanging environment of caves provides biologists with important data. Shows the evolutionary and adaptive modifications of cave dwelling bats, fish, insects and salamanders.

results.title: The Cause of liberty
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, Robert Saudek Associates, Robert Saudek and William Francisco
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American revolution”.
This dramatisation stars a youthful Michael Douglas and James Woods and is based on the letters of John and Henry Laurens, written between 1772-1776. The letters between father and son give a first-hand account of some of the events and issues surrounding the American Revolution. An interesting comparison is made between the call for national independence by America and the prohibition of slavery in England.

results.title: The Cattle story
results.brief_description: Classroom film on the Northern Australian export beef industry. Historical survey shows introduction of beef cattle to Australia by Governor Phillip. Gives detailed account of beef-raising areas, stock routes and mustering procedures, and indicates importance of the industry in Australia’s economy. Adoption of modern transport methods, in particular, has done much to raise the quality of Australian beef. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Cattle carters (A)
results.creator_credit: Greenpark Productions, Cinesound for British Petroleum and Derek Williams
results.brief_description: A dramatic account of road trains in outback Australia. Each year thousands of cattle are moved from the great cattle properties of north-west Australia to the railhead for shipment to southern and overseas markets. Today this journey is carried out as a round-the-clock enterprise operating 48 ton road trains over the tracks where drovers once rode for weeks at a time. Typical is the trail from Anna Plains to Meekatharra - the longest overland road haul of its type in Australia. (Diploma of Merit, 1962 Melbourne Film Festival).

results.title: The Cathode colours them human
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Intel, Cecily Burwash, J Willis and Patrick Watson
results.brief_description: A probing study of the effects of television particularly in the political life of nations. Today politicians are becoming fascinated, repelled, intrigued or perhaps frightened, by the political possibilities of television. The candidate’s success no longer depends on their effectiveness at the door, or in the rented hall. Far more important is their “image” on the voter’s TV screen. What is television doing to the political scene? Does it convey ideas or just personalities? Is it educating or deceiving the electorate? The film discusses these questions. Examples from Britain, USA and Canada are used to show how effective the marriage of television and politics has been.

results.title: The Catherine Wheel
results.brief_description: Twyla Tharp, a leading choreographer, and David Byrne of “Talking Heads” fame have worked together to masterfully crosscut fragments of emotion through music and movement. This breathtaking and explosive piece of dance theatre broke new ground in modern dance and music. Rated: G
